title: Weird
content:
One aspect of the new T26 website is a bestsellers page, and there is some wierd stuff on there. OK so I understand the 'spiderman' font must be popular, but I never really thought of script typefaces being what T26 is all about.   
   
 [http://www.t26.com/fonts/bestsellers.php](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142449/http:/www.t26.com/fonts/bestsellers.php)
author: union

comments.content: It has been my experience that scripts and hands are generally better selling typefaces (measured by unit sales, rather than dollar value) regardless of the foundry, designer, or distributor. What T-26 is _about_ has slowly changed (...perhaps even grown up?) over the years.

Tiff, the script phenomenon is huge and multi-faceted: Grunge, post-structuralism, "non-professional" buyers and font makers, retro, post-print; -- many reasons for it.   
   
Is it as big in Europe as in North America?

Jim, that list is scary. It says more about T-26's clientele than them (I hope)...   
   
BTW, what do you guys think about that Tension?   
I mean compared to de Groot's Punten.   
   
hhp

Punten looks better executed, more coherent.   
Tension is just a serif face with random spikes.   
IMHO.

It's dispiriting that big retail sites are getting a market-driven look that is increasingly "non typographic".   
   
(This is not meant as a diss of script typefaces, but they ARE the least typographic of type genres, in that they don't offer the sophisticated "palette" that a traditional serif family does.)
